newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: ATHLETICS-FINAL SPRINT EARNS MATTHEUS '97 COMRAD.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-FINAL SPRINT EARNS MATTHEUS '97 COMRAD.

text.p: South Africa's Charl Mattheus put in a powerful sprint over the closing five kilometres to win the 1997 Comrades ultra marathon title by more than two minutes from compatriot Nick Bester on Monday.

The 32-year-old Mattheus, who was disqualifed for taking a banned substance before winning the 1992 race, managed to hold off strong early challenges from Bester and South African standard marathon record-holder Zithulele Sinqe.
The three opened up a significant lead over the chasing pack with 26 kilometres to go but Sinqe slipped off the pace over the last few uphill stretches to finish fourth.
Mattheus, who finished second in 1995 the last time the Comrades was raced "down" from Pietermaritzburg to Durban, then surged ahead of the strong-running Bester to win his first legitimate title.
Mattheus was disqualified in 1992 - despite crossing the finishing line first - after taking an illegal substance for a cold before the race began.
"I think I got over the disappointment of 1992 when I came second in 1995 but all of this will hit me in a day or two. At last I'm back and I'm pleased with the time that I ran today," Mattheus said.
"Generally the pace was aggressively fast but I felt comfortable all the way. I kept up the pressure and I certainly didn't want to lose this title.
"I worked very hard for this race in the United States at high elevation in Colorado and, on the downhill stretch, I gave everything I had to get rid of Nick Bester...he's such a strong runner."
Mattheus completed the gruelling 89.9km course from Pietermaritzburg to Durban in five hours 28 minutes 37 seconds while Bester, the 1991 champion, posted a time of 5:30:41.
